sen.j: 妙喜庵（みょうきあん）は京都府乙訓郡大山崎町にある仏教寺院。
sen.e: Myoki-an Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Myoki-an Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Myoki-an Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は豊興山。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Hokozan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Hokozan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Hokozan.

sen.j: 豊興山妙喜禅庵とも称する。
sen.e: The temple is also known as Hokozan Myoki-zenan.
The temple is also known as Hokozan Myoki-zenan.
The temple is also known as Hokozan Myoki-zenan.

sen.j: 江戸時代一時地蔵寺の塔頭であったが、現在は臨済宗東福寺派に属する。
sen.e: During the Edo period, it temporarily served as a sub-temple of Jizo-ji Temple but it now belongs to the Tofuku-ji Branch of the Rinzai Sect.
During the Edo period, it temporarily served as a sub-temple of Jizo-ji Temple but it now belongs to the Tofuku-ji Branch of the Rinzai Sect.
During the Edo period, it temporarily served as a sub-temple of Jizo-ji Temple but it now belongs to the Tofuku-ji School of the Rinzai Sect.

sen.j: 室町時代明応年間（1492年～1501年）の開創。
sen.e: Myoki-an Temple was founded between 1492 and 1501 during the Muromachi period.
Myoki-an Temple was founded between 1492 and 1501 during the Muromachi period.
Myoki-an Temple was founded between 1492 and 1501 during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 開山は東福寺開創聖一国師法嗣春嶽士芳。
sen.e: The temple's founder was priest Shoitsukokushi Hassu Shungaku Shiho who also founded Tofuku-ji Temple.
The temple's founder was priest Shoitsukokushi Hassu Shungaku Shiho who also founded Tofuku-ji Temple.
The temple's founder was priest Shoitsukokushi Hassu Shungaku Shiho who also founded Tofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 国宝の茶室「待庵（たいあん）」があることで知られる。
sen.e: It is known for its National Treasure-designated teahouse "Tai-an".
It is known for its National Treasure-designated teahouse "Tai-an".
It is known for its National Treasure-designated teahouse 'Tai-an.'

sen.j: 連歌師の山崎宗鑑の屋敷（對月庵）を宗鑑退去（大永3年（1524年）ごろ）後寺庵に改めたとの伝えもあるが、春嶽は永正6年（1510年）にすでに没している。
sen.e: There is a legend that the residence (Fugetsu-an) of renga poet Sokan YAMAZAKI was converted to a simple temple after his death (c.1524) but the priest Shungaku passed away in 1510.
There is a legend that the residence (Fugetsu-an) of renga poet Sokan YAMAZAKI was converted to a simple temple after his death (c.1524) but the priest Shungaku passed away in 1510.
There is a legend that the residence (Fugetsu-an) of renga poet Sokan YAMAZAKI was converted to a simple temple after his death (c.1524) but the priest Shungaku passed away in 1510.

sen.j: また、大山崎集落の大阪府側（島本町山崎）には宗鑑旧居跡（宗鑑井戸）の伝えもある。
sen.e: Additionally, it is said that the ruins of Sokan's former residence (Sokan Well) lie in the Osaka Prefecture-side (Yamazaki, Shimamoto-cho) of the village of Oyamazaki.
Additionally, it is said that the ruins of Sokan's former residence (Sokan Well) lie in the Osaka Prefecture-side (Yamazaki, Shimamoto-cho) of the village of Oyamazaki.
Additionally, it is said that the ruins of Sokan's former residence (Sokan Well) lie in the Osaka Prefecture-side (Yamazaki, Shimamoto-cho) of the village of Oyamazaki.

sen.j: これらのことから妙喜庵＝宗鑑旧居跡説は成立しがたい。
sen.e: These facts make it difficult to conclude that Sokan YAMAZAKI's residence was the predecessor of Myoki-an Temple.
These facts make it difficult to conclude that Sokan YAMAZAKI's residence was the predecessor of Myoki-an Temple.
These facts make it difficult to conclude that Sokan YAMAZAKI's residence was the predecessor of Myoki-an Temple.

sen.j: 待庵
sen.e: Tai-an Teahouse
Tai-an Teahouse
Tai-an Teahouse

sen.j: 国宝。
sen.e: National Treasure.
National Treasure.
National Treasure.

sen.j: 日本最古の茶室建造物であると同時に、千利休作と信じうる唯一の現存茶室である。
sen.e: As well as being the oldest teahouse in Japan, it is also the only remaining teahouse believed to have been created by SEN no Rikyu.
As well as being the oldest teahouse in Japan, it is also the only remaining teahouse believed to have been created by SEN no Rikyu.
As well as being the oldest teahouse in Japan, it is also the only remaining teahouse believed to have been created by SEN no Rikyu.

sen.j: 現在一般化している、にじり口が設けられた小間の茶室の原型かつ数奇屋建築の原型とされる。
sen.e: It is said to be the prototype of the now commonplace small teahouses with nijiri-guchi (low entrances that make it necessary to bend down in order to enter) as well as the precursor of the sukiya architectural style.

It is said to be the prototype of the now commonplace small teahouses with nijiri-guchi (low entrances that make it necessary to bend down in order to enter) as well as the precursor of the sukiya architectural style.

It is said to be the prototype of the now commonplace small teahouses with nijiri-guchi (low entrances that make it necessary to bend down in order to enter) as well as the precursor of the sukiya architectural style.

sen.j: 寺伝には、1582年の山崎の合戦のおり豊臣秀吉の陣中に千利休により建てられた二畳隅炉の茶室を解体し移築したとある。
sen.e: According to temple legend, the Tai-an Teahouse was originally a two-tatami mat sized fixed hearth teahouse built by SEN no Rikyu at the camp of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI during the Battle of Yamazaki which was then disassembled and relocated to its current site.

According to temple legend, the Tai-an Teahouse was originally a two-tatami mat sized fixed hearth teahouse built by SEN no Rikyu at the camp of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI during the Battle of Yamazaki which was then disassembled and relocated to its current site.

According to temple legend, the Tai-an Teahouse was originally a two-tatami mat sized fixed hearth teahouse built by SEN no Rikyu at the camp of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI during the Battle of Yamazaki in 1582 which was then disassembled and relocated to its current site.

sen.j: 慶長11年に描かれた｢宝積寺絵図」には、現在の妙喜庵の位置あたりに「かこひ」の書き込みがありこのときにはすでに現在地に移築されていたものと考えられる。
sen.e: In the 1606 "Hoshaku-ji ezu" (painting of Hoshaku-ji Temple), the notation "kakoi" is written in the current location of Myoki-an Temple, so it is thought that the teahouse had already been relocated to its current site by this time.

In the 1606 "Hoshaku-ji ezu" (painting of Hoshaku-ji Temple), the notation "kakoi" is written in the current location of Myoki-an Temple, so it is thought that the teahouse had already been relocated to its current site by this time.

In the 1606 'Hoshaku-ji ezu' (painting of Hoshaku-ji Temple), the notation 'kakoi' (tea room) is written in the current location of Myoki-an Temple, so it is thought that the teahouse had already been relocated to its current site by this time.

sen.j: 同図には、妙喜庵の西方、現在の島本町の宗鑑旧居跡付近に「宗鑑やしき」そして「利休」の書き込みもあり、利休がこの付近に住んでいたことを伺わせる。
sen.e: In the same painting, the presence of the words "Sokan Yashiki" (Sokan's residence" and "Rikyu" written to the west of Myoki-an Temple in what is now the vicinity of the ruins of Sokan YAMAZAKI's former residence at Shimamoto-cho imply that SEN no Rikyu also resided in this area.

In the same painting, the presence of the words "Sokan Yashiki" (Sokan's residence" and "Rikyu" written to the west of Myoki-an Temple in what is now the vicinity of the ruins of Sokan YAMAZAKI's former residence at Shimamoto-cho imply that SEN no Rikyu also resided in this area.

In the same painting, the presence of the words 'Sokan Yashiki' (Sokan's residence) and 'Rikyu' written to the west of Myoki-an Temple in what is now the vicinity of the ruins of Sokan YAMAZAKI's former residence at Shimamoto-cho imply that SEN no Rikyu also resided in this area.

sen.j: したがって待庵はこの利休屋敷から移築されたとも考えられる（中村昌生著 「待庵－侘び数寄の世界」）。
sen.e: There is therefore also a theory that the Tai-an Teahouse was relocated from SEN no Rikyu's residence ("Taian - Wabi suki no sekai" by Masao NAKAMURA).
There is therefore also a theory that the Tai-an Teahouse was relocated from SEN no Rikyu's residence ("Taian - Wabi suki no sekai" by Masao NAKAMURA).
There is therefore also a theory that the Tai-an Teahouse was relocated from SEN no Rikyu's residence ('Taian - Wabi suki no sekai' by Masao NAKAMURA).

sen.j: 室内の壁は黒ずんだ荒壁仕上げ。
sen.e: The interior walls are composed of black mud-plaster.
The interior walls are composed of black mud-plaster.
The interior walls are composed of black mud-plaster.

sen.j: 床は4尺床、隅、天井とも土で塗りまわした「室床（むろどこ）」である。
sen.e: There is also a 4-shaku (approximately 121.2cm) "Murodoko" alcove in which the floor, corners and ceiling are completely plastered.
There is also a 4-shaku (approximately 121.2cm) "Murodoko" alcove in which the floor, corners and ceiling are completely plastered.
There is also a 4-shaku (approximately 121.2 cm) 'Murodoko' alcove in which the floor, corners and ceiling are completely plastered.

sen.j: 3箇所に下地窓、連子窓を開けており、自由な外光の取入れを初めて実現した建築と言える。
sen.e: It is said to be the first structure to allow the outside light to enter freely with its two shitajimado (unpeeled ditch reed lattice windows) and a renjimado (bamboo grille window).
It is said to be the first structure to allow the outside light to enter freely with its two shitajimado (unpeeled ditch reed lattice windows) and a renjimado (bamboo grille window).
It is said to be the first structure to allow the outside light to enter freely with its three shitajimado (unpeeled ditch reed lattice windows) and a renjimado (bamboo grille window).

sen.j: 竹材の多用が目立ち、下地窓、荒壁の採用と合わせ、当時の民家の影響を感じさせる。
sen.e: The use of bamboo as well as the shitajimado windows and mud plaster gives the structure the feel of a contemporary private residence.
The use of bamboo as well as the shitajimado windows and mud plaster gives the structure the feel of a contemporary private residence.
The use of bamboo as well as the shitajimado windows and mud plaster gives the structure the feel of a contemporary private residence.

sen.j: 二畳茶室に続けて一畳に幅八寸ほどの板敷きを添えた次の間が設けられている。
sen.e: The two-tatami mat tearoom leads onto a one-tatami after-room with an 8-sun (approximately 9.09cm) wide wooden boarded edge.
The two-tatami mat tearoom leads onto a one-tatami after-room with an 8-sun (approximately 9.09cm) wide wooden boarded edge.
The two-tatami mat tearoom leads onto a one-tatami after-room with an 8-sun (approximately 24 cm) wide wooden boarded edge.

sen.j: 一重棚を備えているこの室の用途については江戸時代以来茶人や研究者がさまざま説を唱えているが未だ明らかになっていない。
sen.e: Numerous tea ceremony masters and researchers have submitted theories regarding the use of this room with a single shelf on its wall but its function is not yet clear.
Numerous tea ceremony masters and researchers have submitted theories regarding the use of this room with a single shelf on its wall but its function is not yet clear.
Since the Edo period numerous tea ceremony masters and researchers have submitted theories regarding the use of this room with a single shelf on its wall but its function is not yet clear.

sen.j: 見学するには、およそ1ヶ月前までに予約が必要。
sen.e: Those wishing to view the Tai-an Teahouse are required to book about one month in advance.
Those wishing to view the Tai-an Teahouse are required to book about one month in advance.
Those wishing to view the Tai-an Teahouse are required to book about one month in advance.

sen.j: 近くの大山崎町歴史資料館には待庵の創建当時の姿の原寸大復元模型が展示されている。
sen.e: An actual size replica of the Tai-an Teahouse as it was at the time of its construction is on display at the nearby Oyamazaki-cho Rekishi Shiryokan, (Oyamazaki-Cho Historical Archives).
An actual size replica of the Tai-an Teahouse as it was at the time of its construction is on display at the nearby Oyamazaki-cho Rekishi Shiryokan, (Oyamazaki-Cho Historical Archives).
An actual size replica of the Tai-an Teahouse as it was at the time of its construction is on display at the nearby Oyamazaki-cho Rekishi Shiryokan (Oyamazaki-Cho Historical Archives).

sen.j: 書院
sen.e: Shoin (Drawing Room)
Shoin (Drawing Room)
Shoin (drawing room)

sen.j: 国の重要文化財、書院造、桁行二間、梁間三間、一重、切妻造、杮（こけら）葺き。
sen.e: Nationally designated Important Cultural Property, shoin-zukuri style, 2-ken length longitudinal purlins, 3-ken length transverse beams, one-storey, kirizuma-zukuri style shingle roof.
Nationally designated Important Cultural Property, shoin-zukuri style, 2-ken length longitudinal purlins, 3-ken length transverse beams, one-storey, kirizuma-zukuri style shingle roof.
Nationally designated Important Cultural Property, shoin-zukuri style, 2-ken length longitudinal purlins, 3-ken length transverse beams, one-storey, kirizuma-zukuri style shingle roof.

sen.j: 室町時代文明年間（1469年 - 1487年）に妙心寺の霊雲院書院を模して建てられたとされ、連歌の祖である山崎宗鑑の旧居と伝わる。
sen.e: Thought to have been built between 1469 and 1487 during the Muromachi period as an imitation of the shoin at Myoshin-ji Temple's Reiun-in sub-temple and also said to be the former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI - the founder of renga poetry.

Thought to have been built between 1469 and 1487 during the Muromachi period as an imitation of the shoin at Myoshin-ji Temple's Reiun-in sub-temple and also said to be the former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI - the founder of renga poetry.

Thought to have been built between 1469 and 1487 during the Muromachi period as an imitation of the shoin at Myoshin-ji Temple's Reiun-in sub-temple and also said to be the former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI - the founder of renga poetry.

sen.j: 前庭（待庵東側）には秀吉ゆかりの「袖摺りの松」（実は2代目）の切り株が残る。
sen.e: The stump of the "Sodezuri-no-Matsu" (sleeve-brushing pine) (2nd generation) connected to Hideyosehi TOYOTOMI remains in the front garden (on the eastern side of the Tai-an Teahouse).
The stump of the "Sodezuri-no-Matsu" (sleeve-brushing pine) (2nd generation) connected to Hideyosehi TOYOTOMI remains in the front garden (on the eastern side of the Tai-an Teahouse).
The stump of the 'Sodezuri-no-Matsu' (sleeve-brushing pine) (2nd generation) connected to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI remains in the front garden (on the eastern side of the Tai-an Teahouse).

sen.j: 明月堂は同じく山崎宗鑑の旧居とされるが、今あるのは昭和初期に新築されたものである。
sen.e: The Meigetsu-do Hall is also believed to be a former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI but the current structure was constructed at the beginning of the Showa era.
The Meigetsu-do Hall is also believed to be a former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI but the current structure was constructed at the beginning of the Showa era.
The Meigetsu-do Hall is also believed to be a former residence of Sokan YAMAZAKI but the current structure was constructed at the beginning of the Showa period.

sen.j: 旧明月堂は明治時代に関東の好事家に買い取られ現在所在不明であるが、室町時代にさかのぼるものではなく、桃山期後期（慶長年間）のものではなかったかとされている（前掲書）。
sen.e: The previous Meigetsu-do Hall was purchased by a Kanto region dilettante during the Meiji era and its current location is unknown but it is not thought to date from the Muromachi period but rather from the latter part of the Momoyama period (Keicho era) ("Taian - Wabi suki no sekai" by Masao NAKAMURA).

The previous Meigetsu-do Hall was purchased by a Kanto region dilettante during the Meiji era and its current location is unknown but it is not thought to date from the Muromachi period but rather from the latter part of the Momoyama period (Keicho era) ("Taian - Wabi suki no sekai" by Masao NAKAMURA).

The previous Meigetsu-do Hall was purchased by a Kanto region dilettante during the Meiji period and its current location is unknown but it is not thought to date from the Muromachi period but rather from the latter part of the Momoyama period (Keicho era) ('Taian - Wabi suki no sekai' by Masao NAKAMURA).
